title: Collabro come back fighting with "best album yet" after losing a member and being dropped by Simon Cowell

Collabro say they're stronger than ever and back with their "best album yet" after a trying year saw them lose a member and dropped by Simon Cowell . 
The musical theatre group, who won Britain's Got Talent in 2014, are set to release their third album, Home, on March 3. 
The band - made up of Jamie Lambert, Michael Auger, Thomas Redgrave and Matt Pagan - have just celebrated three years since their first ever audition for the ITV talent show. 
It was on February 13, 2014, that the boys travelled to London's Hammersmith Apollo to audition in front of the judges, Simon Cowell, Amanda Holden , David Walliams and Alesha Dixon. 
And a lot has happened since then. Read More Amanda Holden exposes Simon Cowell's strict rules for women on Britain's Got Talent and X Factor Collabro are back with their third album 
The boys sat down for an exclusive chat with Mirror Celeb after giving us a taster of songs from their upcoming album, with stunning a cappella performances of This Is The Moment, Beauty and the Beast and 'Til I Hear You Sing. 
Thomas said: "It's been absolutely amazing, it would be cool to sit back at one point and think about everything we've done. We were lucky enough to perform at the Queen's Theatre at the curtain call for Les Mis, we performed at Wembley Stadium, we've done the O2, the Royal Albert Hall and we do feel really lucky that we've been able to do those things in the last three years." 
Matt added: "It's great because on our third tour we're headlining at the Palladium which is quite fitting for the Home tour because when we won BGT we got to perform there at the Royal Variety, and we've done Sunday night at the Palladium, we headlined our first tour there so to go back is quite nice, it's such a well known theatre so to go back there is amazing." 
However, there is a difference this time around. 
Collabro are now a four-piece after Richard Hadfield decided to leave the group and pursue his love of swing music. 
There were lots of reports at the time of a feud between the band, and Richard told express.co.uk: "There were just really difficult moments for me. There were a lot of conflicting views in the band and there were lots of moments where I felt on my own." The boys have just marked their third anniversary as a group (Photo: PR Handout) 
But the boys told Mirror Celeb there's no bad blood between them. 
Jamie said: "He wanted to go and do his own thing and essentially, without going into too much detail, he was releasing his own music and we were obviously discussing a third album deal with various people and it got to the stage where all five of us were uncomfortable and something had to change. 
"We did the big BGT performance for the 10th anniversary and the day after we just got an email saying he didn't want to do it any more and we wish him all the best. It was not an uncomfortable thing, we've refrained from talking about it out of respect for him, it's not been reciprocated, but at the end of the day we do wish him the very best and this album is by far the best we've ever made and that's not because Richard's not in the group any more and not vocally, it's because we've been able to work together as a four. 
"We've always said before we're this band of brothers and best of friends, but now we actually hang out together outside of the group which is actually unheard of."
